Bruce Ravel's XAS Education Materials ===================================== Talks ------------ These folders contain the LaTeX source for my talks. All talks use [LaTeX](http://www.latex-project.org/) and [the Beamer LaTeX class](https://bitbucket.org/rivanvx/beamer/wiki/Home). All images are included, usually as .png or .jpg files. Source material – e.g. `.svg`, `.xcf` ([GIMP](http://www.gimp.org/)), `.odg` ([LibreOffice](http://www.libreoffice.org/)), `.fig` ([Xfig](http://xfig.org/)), or [Gnuplot](http://www.gnuplot.info/) scripts – are deposited for several images and must be converted to PDF, png, or jpg. The table below links directly to individual PDF files on [my page at Speaker Deck](https://speakerdeck.com/bruceravel), which provides a lovely interface for viewing the presentations on line.
folder title of talk
ATEA Advanced Topics In EXAFS Analysis
CLT The central limit theorem and noise in EXAFS data
Experiment The XAFS Experiment: Instrumentation, Sample Preparation, and Experiment Design
FeS2 The discussion following an Artemis demonstration
i2x Interpreting XANES Data
iiss Introduction to Inner Shell Spectroscopies
methyltin An Artemis example, supplement to a lecture/demo
noxtal Modeling non-crystalline samples
pimst A Practical Introduction to Multiple Scattering Theory
RT The Ramsauer-Townsend effect in EXAFS analysis
secondlecture An introductory lecture for an XAS short course
selfabs Understanding self-absorption in fluorescence XAS
Examples -------------- These folders contain the XAS and structural data used in the talks. [Here is a zip file containing all of the examples.](http://xafs.org/BruceRavel?action=AttachFile&do=get&target=Examples.zip)
folder contents
Au+Cyanobacteria LCF example using gold(III) chloride reduced to gold metal
Cr2O3 The Cr2O3 data from the CLT talk
Cr standards Cr 3+ and 6+ oxide standards
Cu metal Copper foil at 3 temperatures + crystal data
EuTiO3 Data at several temperatures, Ti K, and Eu L3 edges
Fe foil Iron foil, 3 scans, 60 K, miscalibrated energy
Fe standards An Athena project file + several data files with various Fe standards
FeS2 FeS2 transmission EXAFS + crystal data
GeSb A single scan of a thin GeSb on silicon, p. 6 ATEA
Germanium Crystalline and amorphous Ge data + crystal data
HgDNA Merged scans of data and control for HgDNA example, p.7 ATEA
Methyltin Monomethyl tin trichloride + dimethyl tin dichloride + structure data
PbTiO3 Ti K edge of PbTiO3 as a peak fitting example
Self Absorption Data demonstrating self-absorption: Fe, Fe73Ga27, sulfate, zirconolite
Uranyl on Biomass Uranyl acetate in equilibrium with biomass
Other folders ------------------------ + `sty/` + Copies of my customizations of the [progressbar Beamer theme](http://recherche.noiraudes.net/fr/LaTeX.php) by Sylvain Bouveret + common copyright statement, author information, date, common frames, etc To use the style files, the `TEXINPUTS` environment variable must be set with a line like this either in the `.bashrc` file or at the command line: export TEXINPUTS=".:$HOME/TeX/XAS-Education/sty/:" where `$HOME/TeX` would be replaced by the location of the local XAS-Education repository. To use the copyright, author, and date file, put these in the main .tex file of a talk \include{XX.tex} % where XX=(copyright|author|date) Recommended reading ------------------------- The following are some of my favorite papers covering the ins and outs of advanced EXAFS analysis: * [Scott Calvin's paper on analysis of doped ferrites](http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.66.224405) * [Shelly Kelly's uranium on biomass paper demonstrating the use of crystalline analogs](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0016-7037(02)00947-X) * [My paper from the XAFS14 conference on Composing complex EXAFS problems with severe information constraints](http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1742-6596/190/1/012026) * [Eric Hudson's paper relating SS and MS values for sigma^2](http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.54.156) * [Corwin Booth's XAFS14 conference paper on error analysis](http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1742-6596/190/1/012028) * [My paper on A Practical Introduction to Multiple Scattering Theory](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2005.04.021) License ------------------- Unless otherwise indicated, all these talks are licensed under the [Creative Commons](http://creativecommons.org/) [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0)](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/) license.
